message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington’s disease is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene. Gel electrophoresis is used to detect the number of repeats in the gene and provides evidence for whether the siblings are carriers or not. Polymerase chain reaction, pyrosequencing, and DNA isolation and purification are techniques used in DNA analysis but are not specific to detecting trinucleotide repeat expansions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington’s disease is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene. Gel electrophoresis is the most appropriate test as it can identify the presence of this expansion in DNA samples. Polymerase chain reaction can amplify specific DNA sequences, but it alone cannot determine the presence of a trinucleotide repeat expansion. Pyrosequencing is used to sequence DNA, and DNA isolation and purification are necessary steps before conducting other tests, but neither test directly assesses the presence of the trinucleotide repeat expansion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington’s disease is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion, which can be detected by gel electrophoresis. Polymerase chain reaction and DNA isolation and purification can also be used, but gel electrophoresis is the most specific and sensitive method for detecting trinucleotide repeat expansions. Pyrosequencing is used for SNP genotyping and mutation detection, but not for repeat expansions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington’s disease is caused by a mutant allele that results in the presence of extra CAG repeats in the Huntingtin gene. Gel electrophoresis can determine the number of CAG repeats in the gene and identify carriers. PCR is used to amplify DNA, Pyrosequencing is used to determine the sequence of the nucleotides in a DNA fragment, and DNA isolation and purification are processes used to extract and purify DNA samples. None of these options are appropriate for determining the presence of the mutant allele in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington's disease is caused by an expanded CAG trinucleotide repeat in the huntingtin (HTT) gene. Gel electrophoresis can be used to visualize the length of the CAG repeat and determine if the siblings have inherited the expanded allele. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can amplify DNA but not provide information on the length of the repeat. Pyrosequencing involves sequencing DNA but does not provide information on the repeat length. DNA isolation and purification are necessary steps in many genetic tests, but they do not specifically provide information on the CAG repeat in the HTT gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington’s disease is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the Huntingtin gene. Gel electrophoresis is commonly used to detect the size of the CAG repeat expansion, which determines whether or not the individual is a carrier of the mutant allele. Polymerase chain reaction, pyrosequencing, and DNA isolation and purification are all techniques used to analyze DNA but do not specifically provide information on trinucleotide repeat expansions in the Huntingtin gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington's disease is caused by an expansion of CAG (cytosine-adenine-guanine) repeats in the huntingtin gene. Gel electrophoresis is used to visualize DNA fragments of different sizes, making it useful for detecting the presence of the mutant allele and determining whether the siblings are carriers or not. Polymerase chain reaction, Pyrosequencing, and DNA isolation and purification are methods used to extract, amplify and sequence DNA, but they may not be as useful in identifying the presence of a specific mutation like in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington’s disease is associated with a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene, and gel electrophoresis is the most commonly used method to detect the expansion. PCR amplifies the DNA sequence, pyrosequencing detects DNA sequence changes, and DNA isolation and purification are used to extract DNA from samples. While these tests may be used in other contexts, gel electrophoresis is the best option for detecting the specific mutation associated with Huntington’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Huntington’s disease is caused by a mutation in the HTT gene, which produces an abnormally long sequence of CAG repeats. Gel electrophoresis can be used to visualize the number of CAG repeats, confirming whether the siblings have inherited the mutant allele or not. Polymerase chain reaction, pyrosequencing, and DNA isolation and purification can also be used in the process, but gel electrophoresis is the most direct and commonly used method for detecting the mutation.

We refer to Mayo Clinic website for help. Huntington's disease is caused by a mutation in the huntingtin gene, which can be detected by gel electrophoresis. Polymerase chain reaction, pyrosequencing, and DNA isolation and purification are techniques used to amplify and analyze DNA, but do not specifically target the mutation of interest.
